unnormalised: Hey everyone! So, as promised, I’m finally writing about my experience with coaching classes for the IIT-JEE. It's a jungle out there, and honestly, I wish someone had prepped me better.
normalised: Hey everyone! So, as promised, I am finally writing about my experience with coaching classes for the I-I-T J-E-E. It is a jungle out there, and honestly, I wish someone had prepped me better.

unnormalised: First off, let's be real: scoring 90% in your 12th boards doesn't guarantee you a seat at IIT. I learned that the hard way! Everyone and their uncle seems to be prepping for these competitive exams. I initially thought self-study was the way to go, but after a few months of floundering, I caved and joined a coaching center.
normalised: First off, let us be real: scoring ninety percent in your twelfth boards doesn't guarantee you a seat at I-I-T. I learned that the hard way! Everyone and their uncle seems to be prepping for these competitive exams. I initially thought self-study was the way to go, but after a few months of floundering, I caved and joined a coaching center.

unnormalised: The big question: Which one? Delhi has a ton – FIITJEE, Aakash, Resonance... the list goes on! My friend Rohan swore by Allen Career Institute, Kota, but moving there wasn't an option. I ended up enrolling in a local branch of Vidyamandir Classes (VMC) after a friend's recommendation. The fees were approx. Rs. 1.5 lakh per year, which felt like a huge sum at the time.
normalised: The big question: Which one? Delhi has a ton – F-I-I-T-J-E-E, Aakash, Resonance... the list goes on! My friend Rohan swore by Allen Career Institute, Kota, but moving there wasn't an option. I ended up enrolling in a local branch of Vidyamandir Classes (V-M-C) after a friend's recommendation. The fees were approximately rupee one lakh fifty thousand per year, which felt like a huge sum at the time.

unnormalised: The classes were intense! We had 6-hour sessions, 6 days a week. They hammered concepts relentlessly. I recall spending almost 4 hrs every day after class revising stuff and doing homework. It was a grind, no doubt. But it did give me a structure and a competitive environment, something I desperately needed. They held mock tests every Sunday, mirroring the actual IIT-JEE format. My initial scores were… discouraging, let's just say.

unnormalised: One thing I underestimated was the pressure. Comparing yourself to others is inevitable, and it can be incredibly demotivating. Seeing some classmates consistently scoring 250/300 in the mock tests while I was struggling to cross 150 was tough. I almost gave up a couple of times. Plus, juggling board exam prep with the JEE syllabus was a nightmare. Many students start preparing right from class 11, which I wish I had done.
normalised: One thing I underestimated was the pressure. Comparing yourself to others is inevitable, and it can be incredibly demotivating. Seeing some classmates consistently scoring two hundred and fifty divided by three hundred in the mock tests while I was struggling to cross one hundred and fifty was tough. I almost gave up a couple of times. Plus, juggling board exam prep with the J-E-E syllabus was a nightmare. Many students start preparing right from class eleven, which I wish I had done.

unnormalised: Looking back, I think coaching classes are beneficial, but not a magic bullet. They provide the resources and guidance, but ultimately, it's your effort and dedication that determine your success. And remember, the IIT-JEE isn't the be-all and end-all. There are plenty of other fantastic engineering colleges out there! Don't let the pressure crush you. Take breaks, talk to friends, and remember why you started in the first place.
